page.title: 18THE ANTONINE WALL
page.content: The Antonine Wall was built by the Roman 2nd, 6th and 20th legions to keep back the Barbarians in 142 A.D. It stretched from the River Forth in the east to the River Clyde in the west. It was 40 miles long and 3 metres high. The wall was made of turf topped with wooden planks and the base was made from stone. In front of the fort was a ditch 4 metres deep. There were thousands of Romans and slaves working on the wall which took two years to build. Five hundred people lived in the fort at Castle Hill. Nowadays we can only see the remains - of the ditch, a bit of the wall, the wall surrounding the fort, stone foundations of the headquarters and bathhouse, the well and the military way which is a tree lined road.
